newsitem.title: INDIA: Death toll in India building collapse rises to 18.
newsitem.headline: Death toll in India building collapse rises to 18.

text.p: Relief workers searching through the debris of a building that collapsed in India's commercial capital found one more body on Thursday taking the death toll to 18, fire brigade officials said.
"We found one more body today," a fire brigade spokesman told Reuters. The number of those injured when the three-storey building suddenly collapsed in Bombay on Tuesday remained at 10, he added.
Civic authorities, who have almost finished clearing the rubble, said they expected to stop the search later on Thursday.
"It is not likely that there are any more bodies left," a fireman at the site said.
Authorities had initially feared more than 25 people were trapped amid confusion over the total number of people in the building, which housed both offices and homes.
Relief workers have spent two days sifting through the debris by hand as they could not bring heavy lifting machinery into the maze of narrow alleys around the building.
Neither residents nor officials knew why the structure came down without warning. The landlord was among the dead.
"It was quite sturdy," said Hilda Furtado, a resident.
Many of Bombay's buildings are in poor shape because the city has frozen rents at 40-year-old levels for many years.
Landlords have no financial incentive to maintain them.
Civic officials estimate at least 20,000 buildings all over the city are in imminent danger of collapse.
